title: What is the best Elton John album? - Quora

response.answer_text: CAPTAIN FANTASTIC AND THE BROWN DIRT COWBOY. It's the autobiographical tale of Elton (The Captain) and lyricist Bernie Taupin (The Kid/Cowboy): their meeting and their shared struggles up the showbiz ladder, culminating in the recording of their first album, 1969's EMPTY SKY. The brilliant title track - the lyrical poetry of which puts it in my top five EJ songs of all time - marks their humble and humdrum beginnings, uncertain about the path they’ve chosen to take. With “Tower Of Babel” and “Bitter Fingers,” Bernie and Elton warn of the snakes and demons in the music business, professionally and personally, respectively. “Tell Me When The Whistle Blows” is Bernie’s theme, about the big city being too much for him and wanting to get back home to Lincolnshire. (This thread goes back to previous songs like “Honky Cat” and “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road.”) “Whistle”’s partner, “Someone Saved My Life Tonight,” is Elton’s theme, literally about the pianist’s suicide attempt in the late 60s.  Despite it being the only single released from the album (#4 in the U.S., #22 U.K.,) I suggest not listening to it on any greatest hits or best-of comps, as the song has more power in the context of its sister songs. “(Gotta Get A) Meal Ticket” finds our heroes jealous about not making it while others have, and it distinguishes itself by the being the only rocker on the album. They find, however, that, though they’re struggling, life isn’t so bad…if you can’t handle a little adversity, you’re “Better Off Dead!” (In Gilbert and Sullivan fashion!) “Writing” speaks for itself: “Will we still be writing in approaching years?” Well, fifty+ years on, gents! You’ve made your points! This leaves the devastating closers, “We All Fall In Love Sometimes” and “Curtains.” The former, an acknowledgement of their love and respect for each other, the latter, Bernie officially saying goodbye to the farm life he grew up with, as Elton lum-de-lums us into gorgeous infinity. GOODBYE YELLOW BRICK ROAD is usually touted as the best EJ disc, and indeed, it remains his best seller. Others point to the ELTON JOHN album, which housed the classic “Your Song”; some go for TUMBLEWEED CONNECTION or HONKY CHATEAU. Diehards point to later albums such as TOO LOW FOR ZERO (which is my second favourite), THE ONE, MADE IN ENGLAND or SONGS FROM THE WEST COAST. The Captain and the Kid even made a sequel to the album in 2006 called, appropriately, THE CAPTAIN AND THE KID, which, though it couldn't match the heights of its predecessor, was also a five-star affair. Still nothing matches the depth and scope of the original CAPTAIN FANTASTIC. I always say true fans of Elton John point to this disc as his creative apex. Indeed, Bernie, producer Gus Dudgeon, bassist Dee Murray, drummer Nigel Olsson, guitarist Davey Johnstone, percussionist Ray Cooper and Elton are firing on all cylinders here in terms of music, words and execution. This isn’t just my favourite Elton John album, it’s my favourite album PERIOD.

In my opinion, which is in NO WAY fact because I started listening to him like last December or something like that, here are the top 5 best albums by Elton John and why I believe they are the best. Honorable Mention - Elton John - If nothing else, just because “Your Song” is on there and I really, really, really love that song. 5: Don’t Shoot Me I’m Only the Piano Player - This one is one of his more “pop-ish” albums but I feel like it’s really one of his best. Popular tracks include “Daniel” and “Crocodile Rock” but some of my favorites are “Midnight Creeper”, “Elderberry Wine” and “Blues for Baby and Me”. 4: Honky Chateau - This is an interesting album that provokes an emotion that I can’t quite describe. It has some upbeat songs and some slower, sadder songs. The only “hit” that I can think of off the top of my head is “Rocket Man”, and my favorites from the album are “Mona Lisas and Mad Hatters” (my favorite song of all time), “Salvation” and “I Think I’m Going to Kill Myself”. 3: Goodbye Yellow Brick Road - This was the first album of his that I bought, which isn’t that big of an accomplishment because I am 17 years old and it was on sale at Barnes and Noble, and I honestly just needed something new to listen to. It’s definitely one of his more “classic” albums with a lot of hits. Three that I can think of are “Bennie and the Jets”, “Saturday Night’s Alright for Fighting”, and, of course, “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road”. My favorites are “Social Disease”, “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road”, and “Grey Seal”. If you’re just starting out, this is the one to listen to, honestly. I’m glad that I did! 2: Rock of the Westies - It was almost impossible for me to pick between this one and my first choice, that’s how good this album is. It’s kinda short, and some of the songs have strange titles/meanings, but it’s fantastic regardless. I don’t know if there were any hits from this album, to be completely honest. I wasn’t alive during the 70s, when it came out. I do know that there are so many songs that should have been hits, including, but definitely not limited to “Hard Luck Story”, “Dan Dare (Pilot of the Future)”, “Billy Bones and the White Bird”, and “Grow Some Funk of Your Own”. There are a lot of different sounds that combine on the album, which makes it that much better in my opinion. 1: Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy - I could talk for hours about Captain Fantastic and that’s why I ultimately had to make it my first choice. It’s a biographical album about the early lives of Elton John and his lyricist, Bernie Taupin. There are so many emotions that you feel while listening to the songs. Each one is different, but somehow they all have the same sound, and that ties them together. It makes me so happy to hear anyone say anything positive about this album because it deserves all the love in the world and more. Once again, I don’t know if there were many hits from this album: the only one that I can think of is “Someone Saved My Life Tonight”, which is beautiful. I have a lot of favorites from this album, which means that it’s basically the entire album because it’s only 10 songs long, but I will narrow it down to five. The order is interchangeable in terms of how much I love them, so I will do it in order of appearance on the album: “Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy”, “Bitter Fingers”, “Better off Dead”, “Writing”, and “We All Fall in Love Sometimes”. I have so much love for this album and how well the songs go together and for the friendship between Elton and Bernie and for Elton John’s voice to begin with! Once again, these are just my opinions which, reading through some of the other answers, I’m noticing aren’t the popular ones. I really just wanted to talk about how much I love these albums.
